140867546.review:
A riff on the old water-measuring puzzle ("you have a 4-liter jug and a 3-liter jug; pour 2 liters"), with animals on islands instead of water in jugs. That's not generally a puzzle genre I would want to spend ten hours with, but [i]Divide By Sheep[/i] throws in lots of new mechanics to mix it up: some animals can split into halves, some animals displace others, some islands can only be used once, etc. etc.

Is that enough to make the puzzles interesting? Yes, sometimes. Not always.

This is a quickie port of a touchscreen mobile game, and as usual for mobile, the emphasis is on quantity rather than variety. There are 150 puzzles where 60 probably would have done the job. Unfortunately, the more interesting puzzles are mostly toward the end, gated behind a lot of dull ones. The first few hours can be pretty bland and monotonous, and for some people it may not be worth the slog. I [i]think[/i] I'm glad I stuck with it, but it's a close call.

The production values are fine, but the cute/violent comedy is just skin deep and stops being interesting pretty quickly. The interstitial illustrations are more confusing than amusing. The music loops are awfully short. Lots of other quibbles. It's not a masterpiece. But at the end I had to admit I'd had enough fun to merit a thumbs-up.

121522721.review:
Hello everyone, I am the wolf in a sheep in wolf’s clothing made a sheep in a wolf in sheep’s clothing, G.E.M.Simov, a conundrum billowing frazzler, here to teach you how to Divide by Sheep.

 But first, check out my website at: gemsimov.com for more reviews, essays and fiction!

 Simple review details - I rank games on an out of 10 basis, granting up to 3 points in 3 categories, as well as a last, single point from my own self, depending on my experience with it.

Gameplay

 This is a phone game ported on the PC. It is, however, free of microtransactions and other horrible things one can find in phone games. It is also not marred by the filth of common phone games, so that’s a very big bonus… Even if the sheer fact that it is a phone game gives me conniptions.

 So, Divide by Sheep, being a phone game, works with just the mouse. The Player needs to escort sheep from platforms onto a raft, by losing as few sheep as possible. The game world is split into a bunch of platforms (islands), and these islands have up to 9 slots. Most often they have far fewer than 9 - maybe around 4 on average.

 The islands, safe for the one next to the raft, feature sheep. A number of sheep. The raft can fit up to 9 sheep at a time, but it doesn’t actually do that. Instead, the raft leaves whenever a certain number of sheep is reached or exceeded. Exceeding the number of sheep means that the Player does not get a star - and the Player wants to get every single star - so they need to make use of the islands - some of which have fewer slots, while others have more - cut down the number of sheep they’re throwing on the rafts.

 But what’s this sheep throwing? Well, the Player can move a stack of sheep from one island to its adjacent islands by clicking, holding while dragging onto the desired island, and releasing to have the sheep get thrown onto said island. If there are more sheep in the stack than there are slots on the island… Well, the excess falls into the water and dies.

 That’s the game, but it would be too simple if it was so. Introducing obstacles - walls that block throwing sheep to one of the separated islands from the other separated island; wolves that eat a number of sheep and then take up space afterwards; different rafts, some for wolves, some for sheep, and remember - wolves can’t be thrown when they eat a sheep; there are laser walls that split the passing sheep in two (very morbid) but they still count if you duct-tape the pieces together.

 There are many ways the developers have varied up the levels and have made the solutions to the puzzles*  more interesting or complex. I put an apostrophe on the word puzzle, because it’s more of a funky equation than a proper puzzle… Though it could be described as a puzzle.

 So, then… How many levels are there? 30 per world, and there are 5 worlds, so that’s a total of 150 whole levels. Lots of time to spend on exercising your brain, and I’ve got to say - this is the kind of game that’s almost a perfect game, because it’s like chess. It’s like chess in the sense that the gameplay is so simple it isn’t really fun, BUT the act of playing the game and the thinking you do makes it incredibly amusing. Thus, 3/3

Presentation

 This game is monstrously cute. The sprites for the characters are wonderful, the backgrounds and sets are colorful and cheerful - truly lovely - and the whole feeling the visuals bring about is one of… Well, idyllic bliss, really. It’s a really pretty game.

 Not only that, but the visual effects are also very nice, especially the animations. When the Player clicks a stack of sheep(or wolves), their eyes widen and tears form at their edges, as though the stack is overwhelmed with anxiety. That’s a really nice touch. 

 There’s a very nice visual indicator of which islands can be jumped to from a certain island, which indicator is the platforms rising up. It’s simple, but it’s incredibly effective. The sound effects are very reasonable and tame, and I especially like the sound of the wolf-raft sailing away successfully.

 The music is also incredibly neat, pleasant and capable of not getting in your head irreversibly. Almost perfect as ambience.

 Then, there's the way new mechanics and obstacles are introduced - via some very neat comic panels that provide about as much information as the Player may need to deal with the problems at hand.

 Lastly, but definitely not least, there’s the dark humor aspect of it. It’s a bit morbid, but it is a bit funny. When a sheep gets halved, there’s ludicrous amounts of blood, there’s innards and there’s a sheep’s corpse. Then when that winds up on the raft, it just gets duct-taped back together, as if it’s nothing. It’s so spectacularly magical, I have no words!

 I’ve nothing to point at and say: “bad” in relation to Divide by Sheep’s presentation! 3/3

Story

 Death (or what looks like Death) is playing Chess with his companion, an octopus/some unspeakable and unknowable eldritch being. He’s not very happy, but then he gets an idea. If a lot of nice little critters die, they’ll end up with Death. So, with his octopus/cthulhu-esque buddy, Death creates a flood that washes away almost everything.

 And that’s everything. This is just a simple little thing to establish why stuff is as it is, and it works quite well, though it is very simple. Too simple, almost, and that undermines the fact that it does its job very well. I suppose I want a lot more out of a story, and there was very little in this one. In fact, I thought there would be a story-related cinematic before every world, but that was not the case. Alas... 1/3

Legendary Point

 Does this game get the legendary point, so craved and wanted by all and none at the same time? After giving it a big think, I’ll have to say that NO, it does not get the Legendary Point, because it’s just a time killer for yours truly. BUT for a child, a developing child - this game is going to be an amazing thing to give to said child. Don’t feed your kids Fortnite or Call of Duty, give ‘em this! 0/1

Conclusion

7/10. This is a stupendous little game, worth every penny of its price, and even more when gotten on sale. I’d recommend it to literally everybody, especially to parents with kids/responsive teenagers. It’s an amazing little gem.

 I tuck it under my belt, another shining achievement that I proudly display. I’m almost certain it made me smarter, but I can’t count on it.

Reminder to check out my website at: gemsimov.com for more reviews, essays and fiction!

I did enjoy the game with the music and the cute graphic, so i am giving this a thumbs up but in no way this is a challenging puzzle game like the game description suggested.

Insane math level required? No. The 1st 2 worlds require some math to solve, but the rest of the game turned into simple puzzles that we can easily solve like any other puzzles, using the pattern. And each time a new mechanism is introduced, they lower the difficultly back to beginner level for the players to learn how the new mechanism works. Which is fair imo... but when they start doing only new mechanism introduction all through the game, this simply means all we get is the introduction levels for these mechanism and nothing more.. yeah.. beginner levels and not very challenging. I can see how these mechanism are fun and can be super challenging and insane when a good puzzle builder get their hands on them, but the devs of this game doesn't have those skills to build a tough puzzle, so all they do is a repeat of new mechanism and ideas on easy level, they didn't even do a good mix of all the mechanism they introduced, which is such a waste of ideas.

The end comes with a "?" behind, so the game is suggesting a sequel or even DLC... but if they only wish to introduce new ideas and haven't the skill to make these ideas into challenging puzzles, they might as well open this up in the workshop and let the community share their own made puzzles. At least these ideas are really great and can become even better in the right hands.

Anyway... at this point, i can only recommend this to kids. Not to a puzzle solver that love challenges, cuz this will certainly end with disappointment. As for Math lover, you only get to do some simple math at the 1st 2 world, the rest are condition path/pattern finding like normal puzzle solving, math isn't required.

92789453.review:
Divide By Sheep is a puzzle game where the player has to move groups of sheep, wolves and pigs between small islands, and either guide them to the safety of a life raft, or collect their souls for the Grim Reaper.

There are various hazards which could kill the animals. Firstly the islands can be different sizes, and if an island is smaller than the group, some of them will fall into the water and drown. Wolves will eat sheep and pigs if you jump them onto the same island, while pigs will knock sheep into the water. Laser beams will slice sheep in half, although if you send two halves onto the lift raft they get joined back together with sticky tape.

Every level has three objectives to complete which reward you with stars. However, I don’t really like how these objectives work. They ask you to either save or kill a specific number of animals, for example 5 sheep, 2 pigs, 3 sheep, and you have to get exactly that amount. If you save more, you still fail the objective. I would have preferred a more traditional “save more animals, get more stars” puzzle design. Failing by being too successful just doesn’t feel right.

So each level involves trying to figure out how to use the hazards to intentionally kill off a few animals from each group so that you can fulfil the objective. Fortunately you only need to complete one objective to unlock the next level.

However, if you’re trying to get all the stars, you have to perform the objectives in order, which means there’s usually a correct movement sequence to solve the level, and the lack of an undo move button means one mistake can cause you to have to restart the level.

Not a terrible game, but one of the weaker puzzle games I’ve played. I got this game for free as part of a Humble Bundle.

89724642.review:
Here is a short few sentence recommendation for this game:

1. If you enjoy feeling stupid and want to reinforce your lack of math skills buy this game.

2. If you enjoy spending more time looking at a Youtube walkthrough to pass certain levels, buy this game.

Now onto my actual thoughts about Divide by Sheep. 

[b] What I liked about Divide by Sheep [/b]

- The art style is pleasant, and adorable. It comes off as a children's book, and you're drawn in by the bright colors and neat effects. The different characters and objects you interact with all have their own unique animations and it's sometimes fun to see them come to life. 

- The gameplay is superb, even though I am a complete ignoramus when it comes to puzzle games, especially ones dealing with math...it wasn't even complex math...I'm just dumb. There are a variety of ways to eviscerate the sheep and the levels become more and more complex as you progress. I really enjoyed seeing what each level offered, even if I was awful at the game. 

- The story, although not the main attraction by any means, is actually pretty fun. It's told in still images, but it gives you enough push forward to see where Death is willing to go to invite more 'friends' over to hang out. 

[b] Things I didn't like about Divide by Sheep [/b]

-My biggest issue with this game is the lack of an undo feature. If you fail a level, you have to begin all over and that can become frustrating very quickly, especially in later levels that become really complex really quickly. I would have liked an option to undo certain actions. Even limiting it to 3 per level would have been welcome instead of forcing me to redo all my work. 

-The only other minor problem I had with the game was the music. While at first it matches up perfectly to the game, being pleasant and welcoming, it quickly becomes tedious. I actually was able to turn up the volume while playing this game to torture my partner into making me coffee because she didn't want to hear the steady melody no longer. 

[b] Final Thoughts [/b]

I didn't expect to enjoy this game, and honestly, by the end of it I was glad I was done. Not because the game was bad, but because it made me [i] feel [/i] bad for being a big dumb dumb. I usually avoid the puzzle genre because I am intimidated by the complexity of the games, but this game was enjoyable and oftentimes  rewarding when I beat a level I was really struggling with. Give this game a shot, you won't be disappointed!

Dividing by sheep is a very easy task when you break it down.

When you divide  SHEEP  you get (SHEEP = SH + EEP.)  S+H are the symbols for Sulphur, and Hydrogen. 
As sheep need to breathe we'll add oxygen bringing it to S+H20. 
 Couple that with the fact that EEP backwards is PEE.As pee
 is golden we can use the atomic symbol for it, AU. Therefor (EEP=AU). We must also count the fact 
that Sheep are used as a symbol for the welsh and welsh farms. A farmhouse in welsh is called a TY.
Understand that there can be any number of sheep in a field. We'll use the symbol "n" to demonstrate this variable.

By gathering all the relevant data we can use the following formula 

S+H20 / AU+n+TY

The last part is simple deduction
As Sulphur smells (like rotten eggs), and H20 is water. The first part is smelly and wet.
AU+n+TY togther makes aunty. and therefor we get SMELLY WET AUNTY by dividing sheep.

Problem Solved.
Thanks again science.

A solid puzzle game, especially for its price. It's got enough complexity to challenge you, and its full length is reasonable enough to get 100% completion in the time it would take to beat your standard action-adventure game. 

You're the Grim Reaper, and your goal is to reduce the total number of sheep on-screen using the lethal traps at your disposal. It's a game of numbers and logic, but it isn't the sort of game that's going to help you ace your math exam. The game is divided into several worlds, and each world includes a new mechanic, keeping the game fresh all the way through to the end. The game can get pretty challenging in the late-game, but the amount of patience required to figure everything out is pretty tame compared to most math-puzzle games. Since your goal is to kill animals, the game does have a bit of gore in it. The ways in-which the animals die range from goofy and comedic to actually kind of gory. Tread lightly if mild gore bothers you.

If you're looking for a challenge, there are harder games you can find, but this one will definitely get you scratching your head for at least a little while. Give it a look if you're interested.

This is a good puzzle game. It is not [b]that[/b] difficult but nor is it trivially obvious. Some of the levels are very easy, while others are fairly difficult until you see the step you need. You can solve everything without hints or a guide -- there are a finite number of options, so just messing around while help you find things.

The graphics are cute. The specific numbers on the boats do not quite fit the game's story. The intersection of story and mechanics does not really take off until the third world. Every world introduces a few new mechanics, which keeps the puzzles interesting rather than settling into repeating the same thing 150 times with different numbers.

There are 150 levels, divided into 5 worlds of 30 levels. You will know very quickly if you are enjoying the game -- later levels have different mechanics but the same feel, so if you like the early game, you are probably going to like the whole game. Going by achievements, 85.1% of people who completed the first world went on to complete the whole game, and 99.7% of people who completed the game got all three stars on every level. If you are not enjoying the first world, get a refund; if you are, you will have a good time throughout.

I found it most fun to play in small chunks, 5 levels at a time. Longer binges started to feel too same-y, but the game is bite-sized fun. This probably worked better on mobile, where you could open the game, complete a level, then go back to paying attention to Outside.

The difficulty curve isn't very smooth, spiking in the back sections before introducing new mechanics. The new mechanics are also not paced very well. It's a cheap distraction, but it won't stick with me and I can't recommend others race to buy it.

72376730.review:
More clever than you might think! Much like the cartoon gore hiding behind its cutesy exterior, there's a solid math/spatial puzzle game lurking here that continually introduces new mechanics and twists as you progress. Sound effects are solid. The music is decent and fits the cheeky, light-hearted tone of the game...meaning you'll probably get sick of it and mute it eventually. Volume controls for music and SFX are, thankfully, separate.
I have to admit it overstayed its welcome a bit, but it was worth playing.

...On a phone or tablet.

It controls best with a touchscreen hands-down, and the PC port is functional but thoroughly half-assed. No cloud saves. The only visual option is to turn off blood and guts, presumably also in the original; there isn't even a way to run the game windowed. On the upside, it does look sharp at any resolution owing to its use of vector graphics, and I didn't run into any bugs.

I ended up playing Divide by Sheep almost exclusively on my phone via Remote Play, and would advise interested parties to do the same.

Death is lonely.
 Death wants some company.
 So naturally he would flood a plain filled with sheep and wolves, then float rafts requiring very specific numbers of dead creature souls at a time. Obviously.
What makes it noteworthy is the window dressing, a cartoon presentation of fairly morbid subject matter.
It starts out with a simple premise, which it builds upon as the player progresses.
It's smart, it's pretty, and it never dwells on any one idea for too long. At its heart is a math puzzle, but what makes it shine is the dark comedy found in killing cartoon animals just to satisfy some requirements.

67412898.review:
If you like puzzle games, specifically math puzzle games, then I really recommend this. This is a brightly colored game that doesn't take itself seriously and has cute sound effects and animations paired along with it. There is a vibrant positivity to this game, despite drowning and killing your sheep!

You will constantly be counting your sheep (and soon wolves, and later pigs) in order to figure out exactly what needs to happen and in what order. The order in which you do things is also very important, so there is a lot of shuffling. While it may seem repetitive at first, the game pretty consistently throws in new animals, platforms, and mechanics to keep things interesting and you will often be trying out different combinations of animals and mechanics to figure out how they work together. I found it kept my interest with all these things.

The game is super addictive and does not require you to be a genius. In each level, you have 3 objectives that must be done in order. It usually asks you to save a certain number of a specific animal or kill a certain number of animals. Each objective will earn you a star, and while getting 3 stars can be very difficult, you only need to unlock 1 or 2 per level in order to unlock the next world, so mastery is definitely optional. There were times when I wanted to just advance through the levels, but I kept going back and trying to 3 stars because the game is just that addictive.

In terms of playtime, this game will probably take you about 6-8 hours to beat, but if you are like me and want to try 3-starring every level, it will probably take about 20-30 hours (my hours logged are so high because I often left the game open in the background and played it off and on). Some of the levels are VERY tricky to figure out, but the game always feels fair and it's always clever. It is really satisfying when you have that aha moment and figure out the solution.

I would also just like to chime in on some reviews that complain about the developers refusing to add an undo button. They made the right call. If I was constantly hitting undo, it would trivialize the game and I wouldn't really be *thinking* about what needs to happen and I wouldn't be learning all the mechanics and improving. It is very easy to hit reset and each level does not require a long list of moves. Trust me on this.

Overall, this is a great game that gives you all the things you need to succeed but doesn't hold your hand. I highly recommend this one for puzzle game lovers!

[u][h1]French Review (English review is at the bottom)[/h1][/u]


[h1][b]Vue d'ensemble[/b][/h1] 

La faucheuse sème tellement la mort qu'elle se retrouve sans amis et s'ennuie.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2048419374
C'est à partir de ce moment qu'elle s'est mise en tête de tuer des moutons, loups et cochons pour avoir des âmes avec lesquelles jouées. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2048419181
Votre rôle de héro consistera à sauver le plus de ces moutons possibles, éparpiller sur des petites îles au milieu de l'eau, avant que la Faucheuse ne vienne les récupérer.
Bien sûr vous ne pourrez pas tous les sauver, il faudra malheureusement en sacrifier et cela par divers moyens pour finir ce mignon et gore casse-tête mathématique. 

✅[b]Points positifs[/b]✅

* Animation soignée,
* Graphismes colorés et agréables,
* Bonne durée de vie (10/15 heures plus ou moins),
*150 niveaux dans différents univers avec de nombreux pièges et autres,
* Difficulté variée (un niveau est facile puis le suivant difficile, cela varie).

❌[b]Points négatifs[/b]❌

* Une interface qui correspond plus au jeu mobile, 
* Bande son moyenne répétitive  et vite irritante (heureusement que l'on peut couper le son dans les paramètres).

[h1][b]Conclusion[/b][/h1]

Divide by Sheep est un très bon puzzle game où vous passerez une dizaine d'heures à vous demander par quelle façon vous allez tuer ces pauvres petits moutons... 
C'est un jeu bourré d'humour, de mignonnerie et de gore en même temps. 

Malgré ses petits défauts et pour son prix, je vous le recommande vivement pour les adeptes et non adeptes des casse-tête en tout genre ! 

[u][h1]English Review[/h1][/u]

[h1][b]Overview[/b][/h1] 

The reaper sows so much death that she is friendless and bored.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2048419374
From that moment on, she set her mind to killing sheep, wolves and pigs to have souls to play with. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2048419181
Your role as a hero will be to save as many of these sheep as possible, scattered on small islands in the middle of the water, before the Grim Reaper comes to get them back.
Of course, you won't be able to save them all, but you'll have to sacrifice some of them by various means to finish this cute and gory math puzzle. 

✅[b]Positive points[/b]✅

* Careful animation,
* Colorful and pleasant graphics,
* Good lifetime (10/15 hours more or less),
*150 levels in different universes with many traps and more,
* Varied difficulty (one level is easy and the next difficult, it varies).

❌[b]Negative points[/b]❌

* An interface more in line with mobile gaming, 
* Repetitive and quickly irritating average soundtrack (fortunately you can mute the sound in the settings),

[h1][b]Conclusion[/b][/h1]

Divide by Sheep is a very good puzzle game where you will spend ten hours wondering how you are going to kill those poor little sheep... It's a game full of humor, cute and gore at the same time. 

In spite of its little flaws and for its price, I highly recommend it for fans and non fans of puzzles of all kinds!

63642995.review: I, absolutely love this game. It has its flaws, (forced feel to the story, a little linear at times and only truly free and sandboxy when you complete the game, and this is most definitely the game I've had the most trouble launching as it freezes a lot on startup with discord overlay enabled) but I still love it. A lot. Once the story is all said and done, (story is well done by the way, just takes away some of your freedom if you want to make another character and have to sit through it again) it's incredibly open ended. Wanna go explore some caves? You can do that. Wanna go explore the one or two kinds of planets you don't encounter by doing the story? Strap on a appropriate EPP for the weather and go crazy. And the mods. My god, this community is up there with Team Fortress 2 and Garry's Mod with the quality of the workshop items. Some fans have even done what Chucklefish hasn't bothered to. Patched bugs and glitches that were a hindrance to the overall experience. Overall, even with the flaws that this game has (including one I forget to mention, Chucklefish seems to have forgotten about it and have since stopped pushing updates as far as I know), it's still an enjoyable experience. The story is well written (though sometimes drags along), and once you're done with the story, the entire Galaxy is yours to explore. Replay value on different characters doesn't really exist, but staying with one you like and staying in that world, never gets old. Hell, I only have around 30 hours as of now but I'm still always hooked and find something to do. Looking past the somewhat linear story, and seeing the wonderful community and freedom after the story that this game has to offer, give it a shot. It's a god damn amazing game.

59615631.review:
Interesting application of mathematics. In the first two worlds you have three objectives on each level: Save designated number of sheep or wolves onto the raft waiting by the edge of the map (in specified order). Be aware of the character piloting the raft, though. You can't mix sheep and wolves on the same raft. Add, substract, and divide the herds and packs using the platforms and sometimes feeding the wolves and even splicing up the sheep! It all comes down to counting and getting rid of the excess, and then transporting the right number of animals onto the raft. The third world you (or the reaper) will be saving the souls of the discarded ones. Enough variation and new special obstacles are introduced little by little during the gameplay to keep the levels interesting.

The game is a clear mobile port but a well done one. The mouse control works fluidly on PC; Simply  grab by the bunch you want to move and drag to the direction to toss 'em. That's it. Intuitive and simple, yet addictive.

54173171.review:
Divine by Sheep is a puzzle game in which we have to save the indicated number of animals from drowning. It is a debut game produced by Victor Solodilov and Denis Novikov.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

Our goal is to save (or not) animals from flooding, mainly sheep, which was sent to them by The Grim Reaper. On the way we will encounter various obstacles. From time to time, interesting, humorous mini-histories appear between the levels. Creators have made available to us 5 different worlds composed of 30 levels, each is different and introduces new mechanics. Despite nice, fairy-tale graphics, there is also blood in the game! 

[h1]Sound[/h1]

Soundtrack is nice to the ear and fits into the atmosphere of the game. What's important is that different music is played in each world.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]

Fairy-tale and nice graphics are the first thing you notice when you turn on the game. You can see that the creators tried to make the game look its best.

[h1]Summary[/h1]

Divine by Sheep is a game that has an interesting gameplay and will surely draw every fan of puzzle games for a few hours. Everything is accompanied by nice graphics and good soundtrack. The price is decent, but I think it's worth waiting for the sale. However, despite the introduction of new mechanics during the game, the game is bored after some time
[b]
✔️Nice, fairy-tale graphics.
✔️Interesting gameplay.
✔️Soundtrack
✔️Sometimes it gets difficult.

❌Monotonous
❌Short
❌Few errors[/b] 

[b][i]Time of completion: 5-6 hours[/i][/b] 

[b][u]Rating: 6.5/10[/u][/b]
[b]
ATTENTION!
Please note that this is only my evaluation and opinion of the game. If you do not agree with it or think that the game deserves a higher or lower rating, please leave a comment and I will be happy to respond.[/b]

53797970.review:
[h1]Are We Heading to the Right Direction? [/h1]

Divide by the sheep is a game about our society. Developers secretly hide today’s modern problems like xenophobia and racism, terrorism, flood of refugees, mass pollution, social hierarchy and fear for globalization and science (post-modernism era, what can I say). It’s like metaphor hidden under the sheep skin.

Just think about it, this game starts from peaceful mission where you have to save sheep from flooding. But water everywhere and there is a limit for sheep on the boat. In some cases boat can only hold one person (let’s be open to this metaphor). So in order to save ONE sheep I have to sacrifice 6 or more. You can’t ignore that, it’s a clear metaphor to our society. We sacrifice everything to save our own children but easily agree to sacrifice others. Or another perspective, this white person is rich and he pays for his survival. Greed takes over the reason for the life and we proceed for the next mission. 

Wolves are clear representatives of dark-skinned people and pigs will be representatives of the eastern culture. There are some events where sheep protests against wolves. They started to build cages in order to protect themselves. And even if the sheep has been eaten the killer will be sent for life in a small, flooding, tiny cage. 

Also, there are not only sheep. It’s got wolves, pigs, krakens and some mythical golden totem (metaphor for democracy) plus there are certain mechanisms for killing such as lasers, ritual stones, portals which designed to make levels harder. 

Even the name of the game has its hidden meaning -“Divide by Sheep”. It’s portrays some mocking communities (like SJW) where leaders have no idea about their country nor the outside world and still trying to `protest or be offended by anything they dislike. 

As for mechanics, it’s rather simple. Wolves eat sheep and only the ones who are hungry are capable to move forward. Sometimes you have to save them too and there are cases where, again, you have to leave/kill some beings behind to succeed. Wolves can eat even some parts of sheep. You can mutilate them if you ordered to go though lasers. However wolves are smart enough to evade them. It’s a mockup about army because you can save body but it’s already a corpse glued together. In terms of game packed corpse count as a normal sheep. 

If you get closer to the end of the game there will be a death and you have to kill any living being to finish the mission. That’s a clear mockup of religion. Almost every “up to date” religions tells you that this worlds sucks, die like “normal” person (and for some, grab a few other lives with you) and you will be rewarded in the afterlife. Same as in the game but for REAL life there is only one and only ending…

51643857.review:
Like many games of it's kind, Divide By Sheep is a slow paced thinking game, that starts you off with simple mechanics and rules, slowly amping them up and introducing new twists until you reach expert levels of difficulty. The ability to complete one objective and finish the level (thus earning one star out of three) is satisfying for those stuck on a particular spot, yet the game's mechanic of requiring a certain number of stars before you progress brings you back to master them at some point. It's a tried and turned method, with not much new behind it.   
  
The colors are bright and vibrant despite the game's dark humor, and it may take some back to the days of colorful flash games. Overall the game is fun for a short break from more intensive ones, yet I couldn't see myself playing for a long time on PC. It's better suited for a mobile game.

51133275.review:
Divide by Sheep is an excellent logic puzzle game, despite its sometimes hard to grasp mechanics. As a mobile port it's lacking standard PC options, most notably a windowed mode. Nevertheless, it's fully playable without issues and joins the ranks of puzzle games with a clear design and simple features.

The look and feel of the game is reminiscent of flash games, just tidied up so that it offers a clean and unobstructed view over each level. Matching the bright graphics are upbeat music and playful sound effects. In that regard, it's a standard puzzle game, not particularly outstanding, but more than expedient on any audiovisual account.

Though the levels become harder and gradually layer new mechanics on top of each other, they still stay relatively small and potentially quick to solve. Because of their brevity, the lack of an undo button doesn't hurt the flow. Before a new mechanic is introduced, there's a short sequence of explanatory images shown. However, these are obscure, hard to interpret and don't help understand the mechanics. Some of them, therefore, need trial and error testing to be fully comprehensible.

Sound mechanics and a funny, bloody presentation make Divide by Sheep worth its weight.

50733888.review:
Well, the game is just what it seems to be - a PC port of a mobile game. It's a relatively difficult math puzzle (if you are set on earning all stars for clear run with all achievements) with cute graphics and a small dose of pretty black humour. Nothing more, nothing less. Graphics are clean and not annoying, music is good for this type of "time-eating" game, but there is no option for windowed mode - the game is always fullscreen, which is obviously not good for a game you could play during lunch break. Controls are mouse only - you just drag sheeps and other animals between "islands" to match numbers needed, the mechanics are self-explaining, so there is no tutorial.

For a game I got at free-to-keep weekend giveaway - it's a good game. Whether I would buy it or not... well, it can be good additional purchase for any big sale.

50656076.review:
Divide by Sheep is a mobile port to PC of a novel puzzle game. Death is lonely and wants more fluffy friends, so he decides to flood the world to get more souls of sheep. You play as the sheep trying to escape the flood. The objective of the game is to evacuate sheep from the islands onto the rafts. However, you must evacuate the sheep in the correct number for each raft. That means some sheep won't be saved.

Gameplay-wise, mouse only. Click and drag to move sheep, pigs and wolves from island to island. Each island has a limited number of slots and can only hold a fixed number of creatures. Wolves eat sheep and once they have eaten a sheep, they take up a slot and won't move. Pigs kick sheep off the island and take their slot but they keep moving.

Conclusion, do try this funny game. 

[h1][b]PROS[/b][/h1]
1. Free
Yea, it's free.

[h1][b]CONS[/b][/h1]
1. Not My Cup of Tea
It feels like you're doing very boring stuff like accounting.

48230783.review:
Divide By Sheep is basically a maths-based puzzle game, where the goal is to deliver a specific amount of critters to a lifeboat (or to feed them to the kraken). The types of critters themselves (sheep, wolves, pigs, totem) interact differently with each other and the different terrains, which makes this game quite a brain twister sometimes. Overall, the difficulty is fine, though: Few puzzles are really straightforward, but also not many are what I would consider really tough nuts to crack, either, which makes this game fairly stress-free overall.

Given that there are plenty of puzzles (150 in total), one can still spend a good bit of time on the game when looking for total completion (took me about 10 hrs). The focus here is really on the puzzles - the graphics and music are accordingly relatively minimalistic, so they don't get much in the way (although the soundtrack gets quite repetitive after a while). Generally, it is made to look cute, even though the puzzle-solving involves a good bit of critters getting eaten, chopped in half, burned or drowned, so if you are extremely sensitive regarding comic-graphics animal cruelty, then this game is not for you.

If you are, however, into maths that does not quite look like maths, then I can heartily recommend Divide By Sheep to you!

45624979.review:
A Creative and Cruel Puzzle Game.

Divide By Sheep, Is a simple math-based puzzle game about sheep and saving those sheep from the Grim Reaper. It's very weird in concept but playing it makes for some really interesting gameplay and fun and satisfying puzzles.

The story behind this game, Is that the Grim Reaper wants friends and basically causes the world to flood, Killing most of the animals and transporting their souls to the Grim Reaper. Its now your job to save/kill the rest of the animals so they can safely get away.

Each of the 5 worlds included follow similar base rules, such as all the puzzle having a similar pseudo-ish 3D effect and being based on a 3x3 grid system, However to make sure each puzzle is different, each world introduces new gimmicks, such as lasers, which split sheep in half, Bounce-pads that splits the group of sheep that gets on, Wolves, Pigs, Death Statues, Cages, Portals and much more. Each of these provides some great mind-bending puzzles. very challenging to get all 3 stars on each level. 

I think the game faults at perhaps too challenging puzzles, at least if you're aiming for all 3 stars, if you simply cannot get all 3 stars in a stage. if you have at least completed one of the stars your are allowed to proceed, which I think I very kind of the developers to add. One for nitpick is that the Mac OS Version hasn't been updated. this means that the achievements will not work on those computers. Nothing too major, but a downside for those you like collecting achievements.

Overall, Divide by Sheep is a really solid puzzle game. with great puzzles, entertaining gameplay, and cruel deaths. Also thanks to Chrono.gg for adding the game to their Coin shop, where I purchased the game. A very good decision. Not promoting them or anything.

42469795.review:
First things first. I am not 100% sure, but it seems it is a mobile game’s port (made in Flash). Both versions released quite at the same time but it still feels like a mobile game. Why is that even important? Well, if you tend to play on mobile devices as well, perhaps this is important because the game is way cheaper on mobile platforms. So check your app store and maybe you’ll buy it from there if you like the game and reviews about Divide by Sheep give you any assurance : )

That being said. This game looks cute in any possible good way. Gameplay works, graphics and artwork are great, plus music and sounds are not annoying. This is a puzzle game and I thought why write another review about puzzle games. But I really liked it and spent quite a bit time there, so I might as well share my experience.

Game revolves around solving math problems - hence the name. Inherently you are given set of “cute” numbers and you have to solve those sets using math basics for the correct answer type. Those sets are sheep, wolves and even something more awesome.  Always cute :) Answer type is how many e.g sheep you want aboard a raft. Sometimes you need them dead then there’s no raft, but Grim Reaper is taking its toll. Still game logic is the same.
Ultimate goal is to get 3 golden stars. That means each problem consist actually of 3 subcategories or correct answers, if you solve them all, you’ll get all the stars.

Addition and subtraction goes via different max 3x3 square sized platforms or “islands” game characters are placed on and you can jump around those. For example you have 9 sheep (max island size) and you can only jump to next island having 5 free squares. So subtraction is made. 5 sheep are saved, no more free space, others will drown. And if the answer required was 4 deaths for Grim Reaper, that problem is solved. This is just an example because game mechanics to get to the answer are more complex. It’s all math and a bit logic is also required - so if you like such puzzles, you’d love this game.

So I said islands. Game has 5 worlds, each having different island “functions” and each world has 30 maps. So in total 150 puzzles. Difficulty varies. There were some that really took time to solve, I needed to take a break, and come back with refreshed mind. There are walkthroughs around but I seriously recommend not using them - ok if you bought the game for achievements, this review is not for you anyway. 

Island functions. Some islands will explode if there’s no trigger element left on them. Some have non-passable wired fences. Some have a laser field between them, cutting sheep in half. Some are burning and you have to go to trigger island to turn the element off. Etc.

To continue with examples from this game > sheep are eaten by wolves who after their feast cannot move anymore. One char can kill all the other chars on that platform and so forth. Every character has different functions to attend to solving the current problem. Game introduces such mechanics by progressing through the worlds. Mechanics will get more complex but the answers are always doable because well, it’s maths : )

TL;DR This game is fun and if you like mathematics, this game is definitely worth a try. Maybe wishlist it and wait for SALE, because yeah, on mobile it’s way more cheaper.
I really recommend Divide by Sheep.

// 03.05.2018

42128154.review:
Not a bad puzzle game at all! It actually had some very clever use of the mechanics - and in the introduction of new mechanics that were related to the previous ones in a surprising way.

Not a hallmark of puzzle design, but still enjoyable to play.

My biggest complaint is that the game gets a bit too diluted with the constant introduction of new mechanics. The main mechanic, I suppose, is that you have sheep, wolves, and have to get an exact number of each to an exit point. Each island has a limited number of spots, and only adjacent (on the square grid) islands let animals be moved. Also, wolves eat sheep, and well fed wolves will permanently occupy a spot of the island, unable to move.

Initially, all the puzzles involve a certain number of sheep surviving, to get to the exit. At some point, they introduce a mechanic where, instead of getting X sheep to the boat, you have to kill X sheep. I was not expecting this, but it is a very natural extension of the mechanics that lead to many more possibilities!
Compared to that, some of the mechanics were a bit more artificial - pressure buttons that must be pressed to avoid burning sheep on a different island, some weird teleports, a totem that kills everything on an island, etc.

I don't think they were bad mechanics, simply that there were too many mechanics, and the more artificial ones could have probably been avoided to explore the "fundamental" ones more thoroughly.


Regardless, I had a good time with it!

38043730.review:
150 tightly designed levels keep you consistently interested throughout. 

Divide By Sheep is a lazy mobile port. Not a bad mobile port. In fact, its even a good port in some respects. But two glaring errors stuck out to me, the PC user. First one is nitpicking and doesn't affect anything but leaving a "please rate the app" screen at the end of the menus is just bad form. Then there was no resolution/windowed control. And this being a time-filler puzzle game it is primed for being played while consuming other media. Windowed mode (without 3rd party programs) should be considered a must. So alt+tab'ing ensued and I will note I suffered some framerate hiccups upon doing that. The game does look good at 1080p and runs at a solid 60 frames otherwise though. 

The port issues aside, this game is great. The wacky theme and art. The tight puzzles. The bright color palette. It all works. The 150 puzzles are all well constructed in their simplicity. Each level features 9 or less platforms with three sets of requirements to clear. It starts with hopping sheep around. But ends up with wolves, pigs, lasers, meat eating octopus, portals, traps, flames, totems, and more. The game regularly provides new wrinkles to the puzzles. Right when one set of mechanics is wearing thin and you are in a groove you run into something new. If you go for all the "stars" on every level you'll find yourself with a solid 7~8+ hours of gameplay. Very much worth the price.

Easy recommendation to the puzzling puzzlers out there.

34067146.review:
A poor mobile port that is still worth playing.

There are 5 worlds, each containing 30 levels. Every 15 levels or so a new gameplay mechanic is introduced, which works well to keep the game interesting as the mechanics are then combined to increase complexity. 

Each level is comprised of 3 tasks that need to be accomplished sequentially. The way with which you complete a task affects whether or not it is possible to complete the next one and so on. As such, you often need to plan ahead to make sure you have enough sheep/wolves/pigs to save/kill. While it's not necessary to get 3 stars to advance, I feel without the challenge I'd be bored, particularly because finishing just the first 2 tasks is always easy.

The humorous premise and cute creepy visuals, the overall number of levels and gameplay mechanics, along with the (always acceptable) challenge combine for a worthy experience.

The size of the buttons, the menu navigation, lack of options, no working alt+tab, and no cloud saves make it clear little effort was put into bringing the game to Steam. The controls are also better suited for a touch screen. As such, you may be better off getting it on mobile, but it is good enough that I can recommend it on PC as well.

32990099.review:
[h1]The Bad[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Advertising it as a "math puzzler" is deeply misleading. It is a logistic puzzle about animals on platforms. You can express the problems in mathematical terms, but this is rarely helpful and would never advance beyond basic addition or subtraction.
    [*]It's a mobile port and as such poorly optimized for mouse interactions and offers no windowed mode. Click-Drag-and-Release is a strenuous main mechanic for a puzzle game.
    [*]It's thematically confused. It mixes saving cute fluffy sheep with gruesomely slicing them in halves and feeding them to wolves. I'm fine with cute and I'm fine with morbid/gore, but the two don't really mix.
    [*]The game uses no words and tells its "story" in cryptic images which also serve as very poor explanations for new mechanics. Trial and error is inevitable, as you can't rely on the tutorial images.
    [*]The difficulty sometimes varies a lot level to level. It's not annoying and I recognize that different people might find different levels hard though.
    [*]No endless mode or user-generated levels, which is sad, but not a huge draw-back. The mechanics don't really lend themselves to ever increasing complexity and I'm glad the game doesn't overstay its welcome.
    [*]I experienced 1 major bug/crash where upon level transition it didn't load the story interlude and basically hard-locked/froze the game. Not a big deal.
[/list]
[h1]The Good[/h1]
[list]
    [*]The graphics, animations and design are simple yet gorgeous. You can tell the game is polished well.
    [*]The puzzles are solid, entertaining and get you thinking 10 steps ahead.
    [*]There is a wide variety of diverse mechanics and goals which are gradually introduced, so it never becomes boring or repetitive.
    [*]There is way more content than I expected for the price tag. Bought at 80% off during a sale this is an amazing value proposition! It took me about 9 hours to casually exhaust the game and I can actually see myself replaying it in a few years.
    [*]To progress you only have to finish 1 of 3 goals per level, so you can almost always skip levels that stump you and come back later.
[/list]
A definite recommendation on sale and if you like this type of puzzle it's probably worth full price even.

31881641.review:
Divide by Sheep is a pretty simple and straightforward puzzle game. The premise is that Death is lonely, and decides to collect himself some animal friends. Thus, the game centers around killing cute, fuzzy creatures.

Really, the game is at its core about manipulating objects – sheep, wolves, and pigs – around a 2D environment. There are a series of platforms laid out in a grid, and each platform has anywhere between 1 and 9 spaces on it for animals to stand on. If you boot an animal over onto another platform, and there isn’t room for it, it will be ejected from it. If you put wolves onto a platform with sheep or pigs, or vice-versa, the wolves will eat the sheep/pigs and become fat and immobile, locking off spaces from landing on them. If you bounce pigs onto a platform with sheep, the pigs will land on the sheep and kill them. If anything is on a platform with a pig, only the pig will be ejected when you launch from it.

These simple rules, combined with a few other things – a fence preventing ejection between platforms; a laser cutter which chops sheep in half (but not other things), doubling the space they take up; TNT spots, which blow up if nothing is left on the platform, removing it from play; frying spots, which burn up one animal on them per move; burners, which are turned off by buttons on another platform; a portal platform, which teleports back excess animals instead of killing them; a bounce pad, which immediately ejects any animal which lands on it onto one or more adjacent platforms (some will eject onto two, splitting the animals evenly between them); and a totem, which kills anything else on the platform it is on but can be bounced around from platform to platform by the player and is otherwise invincible – make up the gameplay.

The goal is to ship out three sets of animals, in order. Boats come on the top-left of the screen, and your goal is to load exactly the right number of exactly the right kind of animal onto the boats. There are boats for each of the wolves, sheep, and pigs, as well as a boat for Death himself, which requires you to kill X many animals (making their souls appear on his boat), and a sea monster, which just requires X amount of any sort of animal (it isn’t a picky eater). There’s also a boat for a totem on a few of the levels.

The boats won’t leave until they’re filled (or overfilled), and while you only have to get one right to progress, you need to get almost all of the boats filled to unlock consecutive worlds.

Thus, the goal is to get exactly the right number of animals onto the boats using the various platforms and mechanics given to you. The game gradually introduces new mechanics over its length, adding about one new mechanic every 10-15 levels, helping it to keep itself relatively fresh as it adds ever more complexity to its puzzles.

Overall, the game has 150 levels, spanning 5 worlds, and takes somewhere on the order of 6-8 hours to 100%. It isn’t terribly hard, generally speaking, but a few of them levels require quite a bit of cleverness to solve; none of the levels takes more than a minute or so to solve correctly, but you may be stuck on them for ten times that long if you can’t figure out the right trick. It is ultimately very much math-based, and oftentimes the process of elimination is necessary to try and figure out all the ways that clearly won’t work, so you can figure out the one way that will.

This is a fairly decent puzzle game, and the mechanics work well for what it is. However, it is very simple, and unless you really enjoy simple puzzle games without much in the way of story or anything else, there’s nothing else here for you. 

That being said, this is really a game you will probably enjoy more on your phone than on your PC; it isn’t a sit down and play it for hours game (though you can do so), it is more of a throwaway thing.

Overall, this is very squarely directed at a puzzle game player – the sort of simple puzzle game you might play on your phone or a similar mobile device. If you like pure puzzle games, this is a decent game, but it is hard for me to muster much enthusiasm for it - while it certainly was clever at times, and its mechanics were simple and clean, I just was never wowed by it. It is just sort of a par for the course game - never quite dull, but never all that interesting, either. If you don’t like pure puzzle games, or if you like plot or purpose or anything else, this game will likely bore you.

30262754.review:
Divide by Sheep is a fun math puzzle game with solid amount of levels. It might look a like cheap mobile port, but underneath there's a very solid and clever puzzle game.

The game starts simple enough. You just need to move groups of sheep between platforms and get the exact right amount of them on the rafts. But the game keeps adding more and more elements to this simple formula and soon enough you are also dealing with wolves, pigs, dynamite platforms, laser fences and many other complications. 

The constant introduction of new gameplay elements keeps the game fresh and interesting. There's a good amount of content too, especially if you decide to get full three stars in each level.

Despite the cute art style the game has some seriously dark undertones. Many of the levels actually require you to sacrifice a certain amount of cute animals and using the game's internal logic it makes perfect sense that a sheep cut in half by a laser fence still counts as one if you patch it back together.

The controls are clearly optimized for touch, but the mouse controls work reasonably well too. The game also has a rather prominent "Rate this App" link, which really should have been removed from the Steam release. On a positive note there are no microtransactions or gamebreaking powerups.

Overall Divide by Sheep is a highly enjoyable math puzzle game with lots of clever ideas and interesting levels. I'd recommend it to any puzzle game fans.

The good:
- Great puzzles
- Does a good job of introducing new gameplay elements
- Lots of levels
- Cute art with a dark twist

The bad:
- The tutorials can be somewhat confusing
- Controls are optimized for touch
- Prominent "Rate this App" link

28759803.review:
One of the best puzzle games I played this year.

In my opinion it's not a pure math puzzler like other games like Hexcell or Knight. Divide by Sheep has plenty of mechanisms that are more relevant to logic (wolves eating sheeps then blocking cells, pigs taking priority over sheeps, lasers cutting sheeps in half but not wolves, switching platforms, triggered burners, portals, and so on..). Each element appears around every 10 levels, which makes the game never boring and always fun all along the 150 levels.

The longevity is very good, it took me 18h to complete the 150 levels at 100%, which make an average of 7mn per level, please note that I'm very slow, and that around 20% of the levels can be solved in less than 2mn, while some other ones can easily take more than 10mn. One very good point is that the difficulty is not increasing continuously like in most puzzlers, instead, some levels are sometimes more easy than the previous ones, and I never been stuck or felt frustrated. Knowing that the next level can be easier is very motivating. When finishing the game you will be granted with a 100% achievement.

Apart from that, the graphic design is a total success with its colorfull look, animations are smooth and very fun, maybe one bad point is that the screen resolution is locked, but it's really not a problem. The game is also divided in 5 worlds, each one with his own graphic design, mechanisms and music soundtrack (variations on the main theme). The game was made with Adobe Air (which is a very solid engine for such games), and it was designed first for touchscreen (I imagine that a tablet version should exist, I didn't check), but works perfectly with the mouse as well. There is also a parental lock if you want to remove the gore and let your 5yo kid play (it's a fun game for kids too).

If you're into puzzle games, don't hesitate one second.
9/10

28142983.review:
Divide by Sheep is math puzzle game disguised with cute critters. Yes, you also divide.
Let me get it out of the way: this is a blatant mobile port that nonetheless ends up working ok with a mouse.

The basic mechanics have you throw groups of critters from one island to the next, with the goal of satisfying 3 requests in each, be it save an exact amount of them or kill a certain number. These requests are tied to the layout of the map and require you to move around the animals until you've satisfied them all in sequence.
You can merge groups on a single island (2 sheeps + 3 sheeps = 5 sheep!) as well as "decrease them" by throwing more than an island can take and drowning the excess. I should also mention that you [i]literally[/i] divide sheep with laser grids. In half. A bloody half. And two halves make a whole, don't forget!
Things get more complex as the game gives you more critters who interact differently with one another (wolves eat all others, pigs squash sheeps, the golden idol that exists somehow squashes everything...) as well as different types of islands that disappear when left empty or burn any visitor.

While the game is fun, it doesn't have a very good progression; the difficulty varies wildly from one stage and the next, but it somehow manages to be fun for the most part. 
I have to point out that it does overstay its welcome by a couple dozen stages; the last world adds slightly uninspired elements that were most likely added just to increase the duration of the game. The achievement structure also suggests this: the "get everything" unlocks after the second-to-last world, with one more "get everything" unlocking after you're done with the last world as well.

All in all, Divide by Sheep is a cute puzzle game, but I wouldn't suggest it to those who don't already love the genre.
To such players, go ahead and get it during a discount for a few hours of fun; feel also free to let go when you get bored though: sadly, there's no majestic puzzle design waiting for you in its last phases.

26931352.review:
(This Review was orginally published on Gamegrin.com at http://www.gamegrin.com/reviews/divide-by-sheep-review/)

The story behind Divide by Sheep is total whimsy. Death is a lonely little soul with a sheep fetish (maybe he’s from Buxton, I don’t know), he just loves those wooly little ruminants. Being an anthropomorphic personification of the slide into decrepitude and the inevitable surcease of life, he can only be friendly with dead things. As a result and in a leap of somewhat startlingly stark logic, he decides to kill everything. In a flood. Old Testament style. Sploosh.

Now this is where you come in, it’s your task to float the little darlings on to rafts and rescue them from his bony clutches. So far so simple, but wait, they are on islands, and some islands only hold so many sheep. If you get them to jump from an island that can hold, say seven sheep onto one holding only four, three of them will drown and spent eternity as the grim reapers fluffy playthings! Ah well, them’s the breaks. Of course, just like islands, some rafts can only hold so many sheep, so you will have to strategically drown some of them anyway just to get to the end of the level.

And so it goes, sheep drown, sheep live, and as the game progresses you get to slice them in half with lasers (they get duct taped back together on the raft, don’t worry), bounce them off trampolines, and feed them to wolves. Of course, wolves need rescuing too, so them too get to bounce about like little black motes of soot. A fed wolf can’t bounce as that would cause nasty vomitory complications so they just sit there looking happy while the raft floats off into the sunset. While you tax your brain trying to work out how to meet all three victory conditions for the level or at least one of them so you can move on and see what devilry has been set in store for you next.

Visually, this game screams out what it is, a mobile game that has come to Steam. With blocky, voxel style graphics, cutesy sounds and music, and a user interface that screams out “I was on an iPhone” in a loud squeaky voice.

None of this detracts from the inherent addictiveness of flinging sheep at laser beams, fences and the occasional kraken however, in fact it enhances the dark comedic nature of the game and has you giggling at the animated cut-scenes that explain the latest twist to the game play with visuals of bisected ruminants, flying ungulates, and snapping canidae.

On the whole, Divide by Sheep is a cute, enjoyable, darkly comedic time sucker of a game. It has a real “one more level” appeal to it that has had me sit to play it, and then wonder why my freshly made coffee is now cold on more than one occasion. tinyBUILD have made a bit of a corker here, and it’s well worth the 4 quid it costs on Steam

25475190.review:
Divide by Sheep is a nice logical game with elements of brutality towards animals. 
Death was lonely. Who wouldn't be (I know thousands of people die every day. But really - people are boring)? So he decides to have some animals dead to have some friends. 
Players goal is to deliver exact amount of animals (Sheeps, Wolves or Pigs) to the raft. To do it, player has to move groups of animals between islands, increasing or decreasing (mostly by drowning) groups to make them fit into the raft. There are many types of islands, eg. ones that swap places of groups without them killing each other, there are lasers that work only on sheeps - they cut them in half, so you need two squares per helf of the sheep, and you need to deliver any 2 parts of the sheep to the raft. There are few more blocks, but these are just examples. 
Each animal have different relationship towards the others - Wolves eat sheep, pigs always kick their groups amount of animals from the island they land on and so on. 
Later in game there are more raft types; not only you have to deliver few animal types, but you have also ones that require you to kill specified amount of any animal, or deliver exact amount of any animals to the giant squid. 
Overally, this is a good game. Sure it gets hard sometines, but that's the charm of all logical games. With 150 levels aviable, it's a lot you get for 5 euro.

23597824.review:
[b][u]Game Information[/u][/b]

"Divided by Sheep" is a Puzzle game that was developed by Victor Solodilov; Denis Novikov and published by tinyBuild.

[b][u]The Game Review[/u][/b]

Game Visuals

I want to mention that the visuals in the game are nicely done. The visuals can be adjusted in the game's option menu.

Game Audio

I want to mention that audio for the game is well done. Even though the audio is somewhat simplistic and repetitive. The audio can be adjusted in the game's option menu as well.

Gameplay

There are no difficulty game modes to choose from. But each of the levels has their own difficulty.

There are four worlds with one hundred twenty different puzzles to solve. All puzzle levels have three stars that can be earned. Replaying the puzzles can improve the star rating.

The first world comes automatically unlocked, while the rest of the worlds are locked; they require a certain amount of stars to unlock them.

Most of the puzzles are fairly easy to solve. These puzzles may require trial and error to figure out the correct solution for the puzzle.

There are nineteen different achievements that can be unlocked from playing the game. Each of these achievements does come with some requirements that need to be completed before they can be unlocked.

Miscellaneous

There are six different trading cards to collect. Only three of those trading cards are given out by the game. There are several ways to get the rest of the trading card: Purchased from Steam's Community Market; Trade with friends; Booster Packs and its' Booster Pack Creator.

Final thoughts: I have found the game enjoyable to a certain extent. The replay value for the game is low. I would recommend this game, but not at the game's full price value.

21200997.review:
Divide by Sheep is (perhaps surprisingly) fun, even if math isn't your strongest suit. It is, at its core, a puzzle/logic game. Don't let the mathiness intimidate you, if you are wont to be intimidated by mathiness. Players are able to engage in unlimited trial and error to sort out each level, as needed. Nevertheless, there have been 2 times (so far) that I've resorted to YouTube'ing a level to complete it (that's 2xs out of 100+?). So, in my opinion, Divide by Sheep is well balanced; the difficulty increases at an acceptable, steady rate which maximizes fun and minimizes frustration.

It *does* get a little repetitive at times, but Divide by Sheep is the sort of game that you can spend a couple of days away from yet come back to again (as opposed to taking a couple days off and forgetting the game exists) because the game really IS fun. Beyond the gameplay, the graphics are another positive point. The design/concepts are pleasantly ironic; there is a certain (and non-morbid) amount of satisfactory stress relief in killing sheep. Well. Not killing. Delivering them to the reaper. *cough* The cuteness of the graphics provides the perfect offset and absurdity level for what you will need to do in order to complete the levels of the game, i.e. kill sheep. 

One (albeit obscure) criticism is that the comic strip-like stills between levels, which sometimes appear to "explain" new features added to an upcoming level, are often rather opaque in the sense that they can be very difficult to make sense of. Thankfully, Divide by Sheep is highly forgiving - you can reset any given level after experimenting to learn about a new platform "The Hard (but still amusing) Way". Because of this the, at times confusing, explanatory stills do not pose a significant problem. Consider it a pet peeve.

One of the things I found very helpful (even if I didn't often avail myself of the feature because I am a stubborn completionist who will try and try again until I must YouTube because all of the stars) was the ability to wave a surrender flag if/when I was stuck. I appreciated that this was possible even if I did not take advantage of it.This feature would, in theory and practice, allow me to progress through the game (without needing to cheat YouTube walkthroughs) despite only being able to complete one or two out of three deliveries in a given level. The flag waving prevents stuck-ness and provides a lack of gated-ness that many modern puzzle games lack. This feature made Divide by Sheep more inviting and took the pressure off for a not-really-particularly-skilled-at-mental-math sort of person like me. (I'm better with theory. I swear.)

I 100% recommend this game to anyone who enjoys a well-made puzzle game and to anyone who is more pedestrian about puzzlers as well. Divide by Sheep IS solidly organized, thought out, and skillfully crafted, yet it remains pleasing for those who are slightly less particular about puzzlers.  There is no game snobbery here. If you insist upon elitism in gaming or consider "gamer" as a status symbol, Divide by Sheep isn't for you, probably. This game is pure egalitarian entertainment with logic, fried sheep, half sheep, sheep souls, wolves, TNT, sticky platforms, pigs, YOU NAME IT.

PS: As a professional educator, I'd be remiss if I didn't mention the educational value of the game - whether for young math learners, older folks warding off the brain fog that comes with aging (I probably qualify for this category), or an ice breaker for ESL students (linguistic demand is low). Divide by Sheep has much potential as a classroom/educational/mental flexibility tool while still being fun enough to not feel like a tool.

18743834.review:
The only game where you can sacrifice sheep, cut them in half, put them back together and still win! Divide by Sheep has one of the easiest concepts for a puzzle game but yet still manages to make your brain explode whilst still making you want to keep playing more and more. Although, I can definitely recommend buying this as it is really fun, it still has a few things which could be improved which I will explain in my Pros and Cons.  

Pros:
♦ Great Gameplay that really makes you think without making you want to rage quit and never play again (There is the right balance here which makes it fun. It's one of those puzzles you just pick up and want to complete that no matter how frustrating it can be at times you never want to put it down until it's solved) 
♦ Decent number of Worlds and Levels (5 worlds, 30 levels a world, this is a good balanced number as it's not too few levels or too many. It doesn't leave you wanting more levels or make you feel like it's just dragging on and on becoming repetitive)
♦ Awesome Cartoon Styled Graphics (This adds a nice edge to the style of the game)
♦ Sound that just fits (Music and Sounds that can be listened to over and over again without sounding repetitive and annoying) 
♦ Decent Tutorials and Tutorial style (These are set of graphics/images before the level happens. They are well designed and detailed enough to understand what is going on which is awesome)
♦ Not Repetitive (Each World looks graphically different from the last and incorporates aspects from the previous but adds something new. Also each level is scaled on from the last making each level a unique puzzle in its own. This makes the game fun and not repetitive)
♦ Achievements are easy to get by just playing the game (Really easy to 100% if you can 100% all the puzzles)
♦ Star incentive to keep trying a level until you 100% it (This is a nifty way to draw people into keep them playing a level until they 100% it and get all 3 stars for the level)
♦ Awesome Graphical Story involving the Grim Reaper (For the minimal story in the game, it works)
♦ Decent looking Steam Trading Cards, Emoticons and Backgrounds (Really well designed)
♦ Controls just work (This is because the only thing you have to use is the mouse)
♦ Worth the Price of $5 (At a $1 a world or $1 per 30 levels, you will definitely get your moneys worth)

Cons:
♦ Don’t have to rescue/kill all the sheep, pigs or wolves (I found this part a weird concept as it felt like I was completing a Jigsaw Puzzle for example without using all the pieces).
♦ Ported from Mobile without 100% checking that everything is consistent for the PC version. (I say this as it says "Rate this App" in one of the tabs. This should say something like "Review this Game" and shows the Devs didn't bother checking it/changing it for pc)
♦ Can't skip some cut scenes (Such as Intro Scene)
♦ Some aspects seem randomly introduced such as Pigs (One second you’re just playing with Sheep & Wolves and the next you know you have Pigs. I just felt they could have introduced them better in my opinion)  
♦ Menu looks like Mobile still (This isn't a major issue as the game works fine, it would just be nice to have the menu looking more like a PC games to make it look more PC orientated then straight ported from Mobile)
♦ No Graphics or Resolution options (This is annoying if you want to play in different size resolutions or change from FullScreen to Windowed Mode as this is the type of game that would suit Windowed Mode) 

Side Note:
♦ Most people complain that this is a mobile port. In some aspects like the menus and options it is. However, if you can look past that fact, it is a really, really well made puzzle game that shouldn't fully be criticised on the fact that the Devs didn't fully change it for PC. With this said unlike some Mobile Ports, the Devs have made full use of the majority of Steam Features such as Achievements and Steam Trading Cards. Therefore, it's not just a straight Mobile Port in all aspects and the gameplay 100% works.

Overall, even though there are a couple of cons, they are only minor things which could improve the game slightly. Therefore, as the game just works, has good graphics, a decent storyline, isn't repetitive and has a decent amount of levels, worlds and content that will keep you thinking and thinking... I recommend you buy this. You'll definitely get multiple fun hours out of this if you are into puzzle games or just want to sacrifice sheep... So buy this and sacrifice a sheep today!

18185431.review:
[i]Key supplied by developer for review.[/i]
[h1]======================================[/h1]
[h1][b]Divide by Sheep[/b][/h1] (Read on for the full review!)
[h1]======================================[/h1]

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
Divide by Sheep is a wonderfully crafted puzzle game, sporting a beautiful artstyle, well paced  difficulty increases with new feature introductions woven in, and a lovely dose of black humor.

[h1]======================================[/h1]

[h1][b]Pros[/b][/h1]
+Art: LOVELY modern-retro isometric style with great and vivid color choices.
+Gameplay: Clever use of "division" makes for a smooth and fun puzzle experience.
+Humor: The concept of the game alone is pure gold, even if the humor is black.
+Difficulty: New features and difficulty both come at a good pace, although there is sometimes inconsistency in said difficulty.
+Sound: The audio design is pretty good, and there are no problems that stand out.

[h1][b]Cons[/b][/h1]
-"Tutorial": The briefing for new features through the use of a single picture can make instructions a little murky at times.
-The menu is slightly awkward to navigate with a mouse.
-Nobody likes it when the "Rate this app!" page stays on a mobile port, but this isn't a huge deal.

[h1][b]Neutral[/b][/h1]
+/- It would be cool if there were even more options for how to divide the sheep.

[h1]======================================[/h1]

[h1][b]Introduction[/b][/h1]
Welcome to the wonderful world of Divide by Sheep, a fun puzzle game where it is your job to fling livestock from platform to platform to ensure the correct amount get to the end.

[h1][b]Gameplay[/b][/h1]
Divide by Sheep is a puzzle game through and through. There's no run and gun, there's no portals, there's no incentive to click as fast as you can, there's no minigames or leveling up. All there is, is a collection of levels with simple mechanics used in very clever ways, and a goal. That's right, it's just you and your brain. You can take as much time as you need, and retry at any time, but be prepared to do it a lot if you intend to complete every level perfectly. 

Never before has it been more difficult to simply kill one sheep, or feed a few dogs. In your quest to (sometimes literally) extract these cute animals, you will have to systematically divide, subtract, and add to the groups of critters. You have various tools at your disposal for doing so, including incineration, lazers that split individuals in half, drowning, replacing (and still drowning,) jump pads that split your group up and send them in specific directions, platforms that swap with each other, etc.

Sacrifice is the name of the game, here, and it's never been more cute or fun. Divide by Sheep starts off relatively easy, and with great pacing gradually introduces more features and difficulty, although sometimes a level or two might be easier or significantly harder than previous ones. All of the puzzles are completely solvable and require experimentaiton or calculation, but never abstraction; you will never have that moment where you have to look up a solution to a puzzle and then go "How was I supposed to know that's what I was supposed to do?" The design of the levels is brilliantly clever and you will find yourself feeling increasingly satisfied with figuring out how to beat them with a perfect score. Get ready, it's really addicting!

[h1][b]Graphics[/b][/h1]
The graphics in Divide by Sheep are pretty simple, but very effective. It has a classic isometric style with modern design, with an almost vector art aesthetic. The menu transitions and navigation are smooth and simple, and I love how the UI stays almost completely out of the way, however, I will fault it slightly for clearly being intended for touch devices, and for having a rate this app page. There is also no option to change resolution. There is, however, a button to make the gameplay more child-friendly, which is really cool, and considerate of the developers, because this would be a great mental workout for any kid who can understand the mechanics.

If you've looked at the screenshots or trailers, then you know most of what you need to know about the game's graphics.

[h1][b]Audio[/b][/h1]
So there's not a whole lot to say about the audio in Divide by Sheep, except that I like the music, and surprisingly at no point found myself getting tired of it or completely tuning it out. The sounds are pleasant enough, and there's good audible feedback for actions and navigation. There are also no problems with the quality of the sound itself. 

[h1][b]Conclusion[/b][/h1]
Divide by Sheep is an exceptional puzzle game that will keep you busy for quite a while. It is challenging and engaging but never unfair. The content to price ratio is very good, and I am entirely comfortable recommending the game at full price...in fact, they could have charged more and I would still recommend it at full price. Seriously, treat yourself.

[h1]======================================[/h1]

[i]If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Original_Curators_Group#curation]Follow Original Curator Group[/url][/i]
